4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Had cows.

Butter? Had cows.

Eggs? No cows.

What was the price of butter? About 25¢

Did you keep eggs for winter? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

Did you make cheese? Yes

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Bought own.

How did you get fresh meat? Bought fresh in winter and canned the remainder for summer use.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Salted.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes

If so what year was it organized? In the 1830s

Did you use game? Yes

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds? Had some. Suckers in the spring; caught in Tucker creek about 10 miles away.

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ...a well was dug - 43 ft. deep, pumped at 80 ft. depth.

How far was this water from your home? ...about 1/2 rods.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...pail.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. ...bore a well near the house in 1917 - had windmill to pump it, the first few months we hauled our drinking water about six miles from a spring, until we got the well dug, using milk cans, etc., the cattle drank from a slough.

### 12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, lake, dugout)

If so far was this water from your house? ________

How was it brought to the house? (Well, barrel, tank) ________

For arling water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading.

The house in 1917—have well built & pump. By the fall of four months we hauled our drinking water about six miles from a spring, until we got to well dug, using hand cars, etc. We could draw from a slough.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: porridge, hotcakes, eggs or meat, for 4 to 6 people.
2 small children - 2 adults.
Dinner: potatoes, some kind of meat a vegetable, pie or pudding.
Supper: potatoes next, and cake and fruit.

---

Yams, pudding. — two ladies - 8 men - ages from 22 to 27 years. — 1 child about 2 years, and two about 4 months.
